docs.abstract: With a fresh battery and operating system, an aging iPhone 6 seems faster than ever. Why would Apple take steps to discourage a new purchase?
docs.snippet: With a fresh battery and operating system, an aging iPhone 6 seems faster than ever. Why would Apple take steps to discourage a new purchase?
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple’s new offerings are so good that I’m not buying a new iPhone.

headline.main: The New iPhones Look Fine. But My Old One Is Better Than Ever.
headline.print_headline: My Old iPhone Works Just Fine, Thank You Very Much

docs.abstract: Everyone is worried about the power of big technology companies. Apple alone has managed to turn the fears into an argument for its own business model.
docs.snippet: Everyone is worried about the power of big technology companies. Apple alone has managed to turn the fears into an argument for its own business model.
docs.lead_paragraph: The business world has long been plagued by Apple catastrophists — investors, analysts, rival executives and journalists who look at the world’s most valuable company and proclaim it to be imminently doomed.

headline.main: How Apple Thrived in a Season of Tech Scandals
headline.print_headline: Emerging Stronger From Big Tech’s Crisis

docs.abstract: Apple held its annual iPhone event, but its watch wowed the industry. Plus, Google is in for a tougher time in Washington.
docs.snippet: Apple held its annual iPhone event, but its watch wowed the industry. Plus, Google is in for a tougher time in Washington.
docs.lead_paragraph: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline.main: The Week in Tech: Apple’s Watch Steals the Show

docs.abstract: When the tools of modern life stop working, people should be able to shop for the best price on repairs.
docs.snippet: When the tools of modern life stop working, people should be able to shop for the best price on repairs.
docs.lead_paragraph: A giant John Deere tractor and a pocket-size Apple iPhone have something important in common: The cost of repairing either one is too high.

headline.main: It’s Your iPhone. Why Can’t You Fix It Yourself?

docs.abstract: New tariffs on Chinese goods, and subsequent retaliation, could hurt consumer and technology companies. The iPhone maker may be hit especially hard.
docs.snippet: New tariffs on Chinese goods, and subsequent retaliation, could hurt consumer and technology companies. The iPhone maker may be hit especially hard.

headline.main: Apple Shares in a Time of Trade War: DealBook’s One Thing to Watch Today

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

docs.abstract: Three top-performing funds each racked up returns of more than 25 percent, helped by bets on small- and mid-cap growth stocks.
docs.snippet: Three top-performing funds each racked up returns of more than 25 percent, helped by bets on small- and mid-cap growth stocks.
docs.lead_paragraph: Three of the first quarter’s top-performing mutual funds won big by favoring small- and midcap growth stocks, toting up quarterly returns of 25 percent or more.

headline.main: These Funds Rode Small Companies to Big Returns
headline.print_headline: Riding Small Companies to Big Returns

docs.abstract: Mr. Stewart’s knowledge of, and enthusiasm for, a range of musical genres helped make Rhino Records the gold standard for anthologies.
docs.snippet: Mr. Stewart’s knowledge of, and enthusiasm for, a range of musical genres helped make Rhino Records the gold standard for anthologies.
docs.lead_paragraph: Gary Stewart, a scholarly music fan whose enthusiasm and attention to detail helped make Rhino Records the much-emulated gold standard for reissue compilations of the great, the faded and the forgotten, died on April 11 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 62.

headline.main: Gary Stewart, Master of the Reissue Compilation, Dies at 62
headline.print_headline: Gary Stewart, 62, a Master  Of the Reissue Compilation

docs.abstract: A software update will be released next week for owners of iPhones, iPads and Mac computers, the company said.
docs.snippet: A software update will be released next week for owners of iPhones, iPads and Mac computers, the company said.
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple said Friday that it had fixed a security flaw in iPhones that allowed people to call another iPhone via FaceTime and listen in on conversations even if the recipient didn’t answer, resolving an alarming vulnerability that undermined the company’s public commitment to security. A software update will be released next week, the company said.

headline.main: Apple Says It Has Fixed FaceTime Security Bug
headline.print_headline: Apple Says It Has Fixed FaceTime Security Bug

byline.original: By Jack Nicas and Brian X. Chen

docs.abstract: The title of largest company by market value has changed hands seven times since late last year, thanks to Apple’s sliding stock price and the broader turmoil in tech stocks.
docs.snippet: The title of largest company by market value has changed hands seven times since late last year, thanks to Apple’s sliding stock price and the broader turmoil in tech stocks.

headline.main: Biggest Public Company? Microsoft. Wait, Apple Again. Amazon? No, Back to Microsoft.
headline.print_headline: The Most Valuable American Company? Depends on the Time of Day

docs.abstract: Tim Cook keeps taking on Facebook, but Facebook’s stock keeps rising.
docs.snippet: Tim Cook keeps taking on Facebook, but Facebook’s stock keeps rising.
docs.lead_paragraph: The ongoing tension between Apple and Facebook flared again this week, causing a dramatic hubbub in the tech industry. I’d argue it was a nothing burger. Not because it was unimportant, but because it’s clear that despite persistent evidence that our privacy is being violated, it might not matter.

headline.main: Apple Stands Up for Privacy. Does It Matter?
